definition.description:
Graph Structure is a fundamental data structure pattern for representing relationships between entities. It consists of nodes (vertices) representing entities and edges representing connections between them, with optional labeling functions for both nodes and edges.

This pattern is ubiquitous in HCI as it models many natural relationships: document hierarchies, navigation structures, social connections, knowledge bases, and dependency networks. The formal graph structure provides a mathematical foundation for reasoning about connectivity, traversal, and pathfinding in interactive systems.

Key applications include: (1) Navigation systems where nodes are pages/screens and edges are navigation paths, (2) Knowledge management where nodes are concepts and edges are relationships, (3) Social applications where nodes are users and edges are connections, and (4) Visualization tools that render graph structures as interactive diagrams.

Design considerations include choosing appropriate graph properties (directed vs undirected, weighted vs unweighted, cyclic vs acyclic), efficient traversal algorithms, and visual representations that make the structure comprehensible to users.

formal_definition.content: $import(source: ExternalFormat, strategy: MergeStrategy) ‚Üí Effect = parsed := parser(source) internal := transformer(parsed) integrator(internal, strategy)$,
$parse(source: ExternalFormat) ‚Üí ParsedData = case format_of(source) of JSON ‚Üí parse_json(source) CSV ‚Üí parse_csv(source) XML ‚Üí parse_xml(source) _ ‚Üí error("Unsupported format")$,

formal_definition.content: $stream(source: Source) ‚Üí Effect = for event in source.events(): buffer.enqueue(event) if buffer.full(): apply_backpressure() process_next()$,
$process(event: Event) ‚Üí ProcessedEvent = validated := validate(event) enriched := enrich(validated) return enriched$,
$emit(event: ProcessedEvent) ‚Üí Effect = for subscriber in subscribers: subscriber.callback(event)$,
$compose(stages: Sequence‚ü®Stage‚ü©) ‚Üí (Input ‚Üí Output) = Œª input: fold(stages, input, Œª(acc, stage): stage(acc))$,
$handle_error(error: Error, stage: Stage) ‚Üí Recovery = case error_type(error) of Transient ‚Üí Retry(stage, max_attempts=3) Permanent ‚Üí Abort(error) Recoverable ‚Üí Fallback(alternative_stage)$,
$orchestrate(tasks: Queue‚ü®Task‚ü©) ‚Üí Effect = while ¬¨empty(tasks): task := dequeue_by_priority(tasks) agent := coordinator(task) if agent.busy: re_enqueue(task) else: assign(task, agent)$,
$assign(task: Task, agent: Agent) ‚Üí Effect = agent.busy := true result := agent.execute(task) results[task] := result agent.busy := false notify_completion(task, result)$,
$select_agent(task: Task) ‚Üí Agent = available := {a ‚àà agents : ¬¨a.busy ‚àß task.requirements ‚äÜ a.capabilities} if empty(available): return null return argmin(a ‚àà available, load(a))$,

formal_spec.content: ‚àÄn ‚àà graph: recompute(n) ‚áî (invalidated(n) ‚à® ‚àÉd ‚àà dependencies(n): invalidated(d)) Only recompute what changed,

formal_definition.content: $update(changed: Set‚ü®Node‚ü©) ‚Üí Effect = affected := transitive_dependencies(changed) invalidate(affected) sorted := topological_sort(affected) for node in sorted: cache[node] := recompute(node)$,

$invalidate(nodes: Set‚ü®Node‚ü©) ‚Üí Set‚ü®Node‚ü© = invalidated := nodes for node in nodes: for dependent in dependents(node): invalidated := invalidated ‚à™ invalidate({dependent}) return invalidated$,
$recompute(node: Node) ‚Üí Value = inputs := {cache[d] : d ‚àà dependencies(node)} return node.compute(inputs)$,

formal_spec.content: ‚àÄb ‚àà BaseData: base_fields(combine(b, enrichments)) = b Original data preserved,
‚àÄe‚ÇÅ, e‚ÇÇ ‚àà enrichers: e‚ÇÅ and e‚ÇÇ can execute in parallel,
failure(enricher_i) ‚áè failure(entire_flow) Flow continues with available enrichments,

formal_definition.content: $enrich(base: BaseData) ‚Üí EnrichedData = enrichments := parallel_map(enrichers, Œªe: e.enrich(base)) successful := {e : e ‚àà enrichments ‚àß ¬¨is_error(e)} return combine(base, successful)$,
$combine(base: BaseData, enrichments: Set‚ü®Enrichment‚ü©) ‚Üí EnrichedData = result := base for enrichment in enrichments: result := merge(result, enrichment) return result$,

formal_spec.content: lim_{t‚Üí‚àû} improvement(model_t) ‚Üí 0 Eventually reaches optimal or near-optimal,

formal_definition.content: $loop(environment: Environment) ‚Üí Effect = observations := [] model := initialize_model() while running: obs := observe(environment) observations := observations + [obs] if should_update(observations): model := learn(observations) policy := update(model) actions := apply(policy, environment)$,
$learn(observations: Observations) ‚Üí Model = features := extract_features(observations) model := train(features, current_model) validate(model, validation_set) return model$,
$apply(policy: Policy, env: Environment) ‚Üí Actions = state := env.current_state() action := policy.select_action(state) env.execute(action) return action$,

formal_spec.content: ‚àÄd ‚àà Data: validate(d) finds all violations according to defined rules,

formal_definition.content: $execute(data: Data) ‚Üí Report = violations := validate(data) if empty(violations): return Success else: for v in violations: report(v) if auto_correctable(v): correction := correct(v) if verify(correction): apply(correction)$,

$validate(data: Data) ‚Üí Set‚ü®Violation‚ü© = violations := {} for rule in rules: if ¬¨rule.check(data): violations := violations ‚à™ {Violation(rule, location(data), severity(rule))} return violations$,
$correct(violation: Violation) ‚Üí Correction = if has_automatic_fix(violation): return Automatic(generate_fix(violation)) else: return Manual(suggest_fix(violation))$,

formal_definition.content: $personalize(user: UserId) ‚Üí Effect = events := track(user) preferences := infer(events) config := personalize(preferences, user.explicit_settings) apply(config, user.session)$,

$infer(events: Sequence‚ü®Event‚ü©) ‚Üí Preferences = features := extract_features(events) patterns := find_patterns(features) preferences := {} for (feature, pattern) in patterns: score := calculate_affinity(pattern) preferences[feature] := score return preferences$,

formal_spec.content: state changes ‚Üí render(state) ‚Üí diff ‚Üí patch ‚Üí updated DOM Automatic propagation,
‚àÄs‚ÇÅ, s‚ÇÇ ‚àà State: patch(diff(render(s‚ÇÅ), render(s‚ÇÇ))) applies minimal changes,

formal_definition.content: $update(new_state: State) ‚Üí Effect = old_vdom := render(current_state) new_vdom := render(new_state) patch := diff(old_vdom, new_vdom) apply_patch(patch, real_dom) current_state := new_state$,

$diff(old: VirtualDOM, new: VirtualDOM) ‚Üí Patch = if old = new: return [] if different_type(old, new): return [Replace(old, new)] if different_props(old, new): ops := [UpdateProps(old, new)] else: ops := [] ops := ops + diff_children(old.children, new.children) return ops$,

$apply_patch(patch: Patch, dom: RealDOM) ‚Üí Effect = for op in patch: case op of Insert(node, parent, index) ‚Üí parent.insert_child(node, index) Update(node, props) ‚Üí node.update_properties(props) Delete(node) ‚Üí node.remove() Move(node, new_parent, new_index) ‚Üí move(node, new_parent, new_index)$,

formal_definition.content: $notify(event: Event) ‚Üí Effect = notification := trigger(event) if should_suppress(notification): return channels := route(notification) for channel in channels: message := format(notification, channel) deliver(message, channel) log_delivery(notification, channel)$,

$route(notification: Notification) ‚Üí Set‚ü®Channel‚ü© = user := notification.recipient preferences := user.notification_preferences channels := {} case notification.priority of Urgent ‚Üí channels := all_channels(user) High ‚Üí channels := preferred_channels(user) ‚à™ {InApp} Normal ‚Üí channels := preferred_channels(user) Low ‚Üí channels := {InApp} return channels ‚à© enabled_channels(preferences, notification.type)$,

$format(notification: Notification, channel: Channel) ‚Üí Message = case channel of Email ‚Üí format_email(notification.subject, notification.body, notification.action_url) Push ‚Üí format_push(notification.title, notification.short_text, notification.icon) SMS ‚Üí format_sms(notification.short_text, max_length=160) InApp ‚Üí format_in_app(notification.full_content) Webhook ‚Üí format_json(notification)$,

definition.description:
The Canvas pattern provides an infinite, zoomable workspace for visual creativity and spatial thinking. Unlike traditional fixed-viewport interfaces, a canvas allows users to pan across unbounded space and zoom to different levels of detail, creating a fluid environment for design, diagramming, and spatial organization.

This pattern is fundamental to modern design tools and visual thinking applications. It transforms the computer screen from a fixed window into a portal that can move across unlimited creative space. Users can work at any scale, from detailed pixel-level editing to bird's-eye view of entire projects.

Key applications include: (1) Design tools like Figma and Sketch for UI/UX design, (2) Diagramming tools like Miro and Mural for collaborative mapping, (3) Note-taking apps like Scapple for spatial knowledge organization, and (4) CAD software for technical drawing and modeling.

Design considerations include smooth pan and zoom animations, maintaining orientation in unbounded space, handling performance with large numbers of elements, providing minimap or overview navigation, and supporting both keyboard and touch gestures for navigation.

component.name: Path_{retrieval}
component.description: sequence of nodes and edges traversed in graph

formal_spec.content: $\forall (n_i, e_i) \in Path_{retrieval} : \text{explain}(e_i) \to \text{why } n_{i} \to n_{i+1}$ (each hop justified),
$\forall n_i, n_{i+1} \in Path_{retrieval} : Score_{relevance}(n_{i+1}) \leq Score_{relevance}(n_i)$ (decreasing along path),
$\forall i : \exists e \in \text{Edges} : e.source = n_i \land e.target = n_{i+1}$ (valid graph path),

formal_definition.content: $\text{traceRetrieval}(q, G) = \text{path}$where$n_0 = \arg\max_{n \in G} \text{sim}(q.embedding, n.embedding)$$path = [n_0] \oplus \text{expand}(n_0, q, k)$(k-hop expansion),

$\text{visualizePath}(path) = \text{render}$where$\text{render}.nodes = \{n \mid (n, e) \in path\}$$\text{render}.edges = \{e \mid (n, e) \in path\}$$\text{render}.highlights = \text{relevance-based colors}$,
$\text{scorePath}(path) = \sum_{i=1}^{|path|} \frac{Score_{relevance}(n_i)}{i^\alpha}$(decaying sum,$\alpha > 0$),

component.name: Colors
component.description: color scale from low to high confidence

formal_spec.content: $\forall span \in Text : \exists c \in [0,1] : Conf_{scores}(span) = c$ (every span has confidence),
$\forall i, j : i < j \implies Thresholds[i] < Thresholds[j]$ (increasing sequence),
$\forall t_i, t_{i+1} \in Thresholds : \Delta E(Colors(t_i), Colors(t_{i+1})) > \tau$ (perceptually distinct),

formal_definition.content: $\text{applyHighlighting}(text, conf) = \text{styled}$where$\forall span \in text : \text{styled}[span].color = Colors(conf(span))$,

$\text{categorize}(c) = \begin{cases} \text{high} & \text{if } c \geq t_3 \\ \text{medium} & \text{if } t_2 \leq c < t_3 \\ \text{low} & \text{if } t_1 \leq c < t_2 \\ \text{uncertain} & \text{if } c < t_1 \end{cases}$where$t_1, t_2, t_3 \in Thresholds$,
$\text{interpolate}(c) = (1-c) \cdot \text{color}_{low} + c \cdot \text{color}_{high}$(linear gradient),

component.name: Sources
component.description: multiple sources making potentially conflicting claims

formal_spec.content: $\forall c_1, c_2 \in \text{Claims} : \text{contradicts}(c_1, c_2) \implies (c_1, c_2, t) \in Conflicts$ for some $t$,

formal_definition.content: $\text{detectConflicts}(S) = \{(c_1, c_2, t) \mid$$(s_1, c_1), (s_2, c_2) \in S \land s_1 \neq s_2 \land$$t = \text{classifyConflict}(c_1, c_2)\}$,

$\text{resolve}(c_1, c_2, t) = r$where$r.merged\_claim = \text{merge}(c_1, c_2, t)$$r.consensus\_score = \frac{|\text{supporting}(r)|}{|\text{all\_sources}|}$$r.dissenting = \{s \mid s \text{ contradicts } r\}$,

$\text{visualizeDisagreement}(r) = \text{view}$where$\text{view}.main = r.merged\_claim$$\text{view}.alternatives = \{c \mid c \in r.dissenting\}$$\text{view}.consensus\_bar = r.consensus\_score \times 100\%$,

definition.content: $\text{Graph} = (V, E, \lambda_V, \lambda_E)$ where $V$ are vertices, $E \subseteq V \times V$ edges, $\lambda$ label functions

formal_definition.content: $\text{addNode}(q, n) = q'$where$q'.nodes = q.nodes \cup \{n\}$$q'.constraints = q.constraints \cup \text{constraintsOf}(n)$,
$\text{compile}(q) = \text{cypher}$where$\text{cypher} = \text{MATCH } \text{pattern}(q.nodes, q.edges)$$\text{ WHERE } \text{constraints}(q.constraints)$$\text{ RETURN } \text{variables}(q.nodes)$,
$\text{execute}(cypher, G) = \{b \mid b : \text{Var} \to V \land \text{satisfies}(b, cypher, G)\}$,

component.name: Concepts
component.description: set of semantic concepts to compare

formal_spec.content: $\forall c_1, c_2 \in Concepts : Sim_{matrix}(c_1, c_2) = Sim_{matrix}(c_2, c_1)$ (symmetric),
$\forall c_1, c_2 : Sim_{matrix}(c_1, c_2) > Sim_{matrix}(c_1, c_3) \implies$ $\|Layout(c_1) - Layout(c_2)\| < \|Layout(c_1) - Layout(c_3)\|$ (spatial proximity reflects similarity),
$\forall c_1, c_2 : Sim_{matrix}(c_1, c_2) < Threshold \implies \neg \text{visible}(\text{edge}(c_1, c_2))$,

formal_definition.content: $\text{computeSimilarity}(C, metric) = M$where$M[i,j] = \text{metric}(c_i.embedding, c_j.embedding)$$\text{for cosine: } M[i,j] = \frac{e_i \cdot e_j}{\|e_i\| \|e_j\|}$,
$\text{generateLayout}(M, alg) = L$where$L = \arg\min_{L'} \sum_{i,j} (M[i,j] - \frac{1}{\|L'(c_i) - L'(c_j)\|}^2$(stress minimization),
$\text{filter}(M, \theta) = \{(c_i, c_j) \mid M[i,j] \geq \theta \land i \neq j\}$,

definition.content: (id: ID, status: Status, execute: Task ‚Üí Result)

formal_definition.content: $dispatch(task: Task) ‚Üí Effect = tasks := enqueue(tasks, task, task.priority) if ‚àÉagent: agent.status = Idle: assign(agent, task)$,
$assign(agent: Agent, task: Task) ‚Üí Effect = agent.status := Busy(task) result := agent.execute(task) results[task] := result agent.status := Idle try_assign_next(agent)$,
$aggregate() ‚Üí Result = if ‚àÄtask ‚àà tasks: task ‚àà keys(results): coord.aggregate(results)$,
Idle agents take tasks from busy agents' queues Good load balancing,
Central queue, agents pull tasks when idle Simple, fair,
High-priority tasks executed first Supports urgency,

$cleanup(browser: Browser) ‚Üí Effect = browser.delete_cookies() browser.clear_local_storage() browser.quit() Page objects encapsulate UI structure: class LoginPage: locators = { username_input: CSS("#username"), password_input: CSS("#password"), login_button: CSS("button[type=submit]"), error_message: CSS(".error") } def login(username: String, password: String) ‚Üí Effect: this.find(username_input).type(username) this.find(password_input).type(password) this.find(login_button).click() def get_error() ‚Üí String: return this.find(error_message).text() class DashboardPage: locators = { welcome_message: CSS(".welcome"), logout_button: CSS("#logout") } def is_displayed() ‚Üí ùîπ: return this.find(welcome_message).is_visible() def logout() ‚Üí Effect: this.find(logout_button).click() e2e_test_user_login_flow() // Setup = browser := launch_browser(Chrome) test_user := create_test_user("testuser", "password123") // Navigate to login page login_page := LoginPage(browser) browser.navigate("https://app.example.com/login") // Execute login login_page.login("testuser", "password123") // Verify redirect to dashboard dashboard := DashboardPage(browser) assert(dashboard.is_displayed()) assert(contains(dashboard.welcome_message, "Welcome, testuser")) // Execute logout dashboard.logout() // Verify redirect to login assert(login_page.is_displayed()) // Cleanup delete_test_user(test_user) browser.quit() Browser actions: - navigate(url) - refresh() - back() - forward() - take_screenshot() - execute_script(js) Element actions: - find(locator) ‚Üí Element - click() - type(text) - clear() - submit() - select(option) - hover() - drag_and_drop(source, target) Waits: - wait_for_element(locator, timeout) - wait_for_visibility(element, timeout) - wait_for_text(element, text, timeout) - wait_for_url(url, timeout) Assertions: - assert_visible(element) - assert_text(element, expected) - assert_url(expected) - assert_title(expected) - assert_element_count(locator, count) 1. Use Page Objects: Encapsulate page structure Reusable across tests Easier maintenance 2. Explicit Waits: Wait for specific conditions Don't use sleep() Handle async behavior 3. Independent Tests: Each test starts from clean state No dependencies between tests Can run in any order 4. Minimize Test Data: Use minimum data needed Clean up after test Avoid shared test data 5. Stable Locators: Use IDs or data attributes Avoid brittle CSS selectors Don't rely on text content Test Environments:** Headless mode: browser := Chrome(headless=true) Faster, no GUI Good for CI/CD Grid/Cloud: Run tests on multiple browsers in parallel Selenium Grid, BrowserStack, Sauce Labs Docker: Consistent environment Isolated tests Easy CI/CD integration$,

component.name: stream

definition.description:
Generative UI is an AI-native pattern where user interfaces are dynamically generated by language models based on context and intent, rather than being pre-designed and statically rendered. Instead of traditional component libraries with fixed layouts, the system generates UI components, layouts, and interactions on-the-fly by interpreting user needs and available data.

This pattern represents a fundamental shift from declarative UI frameworks to generative approaches. The AI acts as an interface designer that continuously adapts the presentation layer to match user context, data characteristics, and task requirements. It enables applications to present information in optimal formats without requiring developers to anticipate every possible visualization or interaction pattern.

Generative UI is particularly valuable for: (1) Data exploration tools where the optimal visualization depends on data structure, (2) Personalized interfaces that adapt to individual user preferences and expertise levels, (3) Complex domain applications where interface requirements are too diverse to pre-design, and (4) Conversational AI systems that need to present rich, interactive content beyond text responses.

Key design considerations include ensuring generated UIs are accessible, maintaining consistency while allowing flexibility, providing appropriate user control over generation, and handling graceful degradation when generation quality is uncertain.

component.name: tools
component.description: Available tools that agents can invoke

definition.description:
Tool Execution Visualization provides real-time visibility into agent tool usage, showing which tools are being invoked, their parameters, execution status, and results. This pattern is essential for AI agent systems where understanding tool usage builds user trust and enables debugging.

In multi-agent or autonomous systems, agents interact with external tools and APIs to accomplish tasks. Without visualization, these interactions are opaque black boxes. This pattern makes tool execution transparent, showing users exactly what their agents are doing and why.

Key applications include: (1) AI coding assistants showing file operations and API calls, (2) Research agents displaying database queries and web searches, (3) Automation platforms visualizing workflow tool executions, and (4) Development environments showing build tool invocations.

Design considerations include balancing information density with comprehensibility, grouping related tool calls, highlighting errors and retries, providing drill-down for detailed parameters, and maintaining performance with high-frequency tool usage.

formal_spec.content: Completed ‚à™ {Current} ‚à™ Remaining = {0..|Steps|-1} ‚àß these sets are pairwise disjoint,

property.description: Every step is in exactly one state: completed, current, or remaining

formal_definition.content: advance() = Completed := Completed ‚à™ {Current}; Current := Current + 1; Remaining := Remaining \\ {Current},
get_progress() = |Completed| / |Steps|,
status(i) = if i ‚àà Completed then Done else if i = Current then InProgress else Pending,
